citations.network_model: Taylor, P.J. (2001). Specification of the world city network. Geographical Analysis, 33(2), 181-194.
citations.service_scale: Taylor, P.J. (2001), Table 1: Service values scale 0-5
citations.regions: Taylor et al. (2011). Global Urban Analysis: A Survey of Cities in Globalization. Earthscan.
citations.crisis_periods: Reinhart, C. & Rogoff, K. (2009). This Time is Different; IMF (2020). World Economic Outlook.
citations.global_city_theory: Sassen, S. (2001). The Global City: New York, London, Tokyo. Princeton University Press.
citations.network_society: Castells, M. (2000). The Rise of the Network Society. Blackwell.
citations.statistical_thresholds: Cohen, J. (1988). Statistical Power Analysis for the Behavioral Sciences.
citations.institutional_thickness: Amin, A. & Thrift, N. (1995). Institutional issues for the European regions. Economy and Society, 24(1).
citations.world_regions: United Nations Statistics Division (2020). Standard country or area codes for statistical use (M49).
citations.firm_classification: Beaverstock, J.V. et al. (2000). Globalization and world cities: measurement methodologies.
citations.aps_sectors: Beaverstock, J.V., Smith, R.G. and Taylor, P.J. (1999). A roster of world cities. Cities, 16(6), 445-458.

methodological_notes.institutional_weights: Equal weights to avoid bias in absence of empirical justification
methodological_notes.synergy_calculation: Actual values reported without artificial capping
methodological_notes.normalization: Following GaWC convention where max GNC (typically London) = 100%
methodological_notes.aps_sectors: All six APS sectors analyzed per Beaverstock et al. (1999)
